title: 108_hr3632
content:
The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" is also known as the "Anti-counterfeiting Amendments Act of 2004." It includes provisions prohibiting trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to various types of works. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to various types of works, including computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, visual art, and packaging. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to various types of works. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Amendments include changes to subsection (b) regarding different types of works and copyright owner definitions. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to various types of works. Offenders can face fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. Amendments include defining the term 'illicit label' as a genuine certificate or labeling component used by the copyright owner to verify works. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to various types of works. The term 'illicit label' is defined as a genuine certificate used by the copyright owner to verify works and is distributed without authorization. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to works of visual art or packaging without authorization from the copyright owner. This includes distributing illicit labels intended for genuine certificates or licensing documents. The act prohibits trafficking in counterfeit labels or documentation affixed to works of art without authorization from the copyright owner, including falsifying certificates to designate a higher number of licensed users. The act prohibits trafficking in counterfeit documentation or packaging that appears genuine but is not authentic. The act defines counterfeit documentation or packaging as items that appear genuine but are not authentic, such as labels affixed to copyrighted sound recordings or musical works. The act defines counterfeit documentation or packaging as items that appear genuine but are not authentic, such as labels affixed to copyrighted works like sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual art. The act defines counterfeit documentation or packaging as items that appear genuine but are not authentic, such as labels affixed to copyrighted works like sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual art. It includes copyrighted musical work, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, pictorial, graphic, or sculptural works, visual art, and copyrighted documentation or packaging. Amendments include removing references to computer programs and adding illicit labels to counterfeit labels. The act defines counterfeit documentation or packaging as items that appear genuine but are not authentic, such as labels affixed to copyrighted works like sound recordings, motion pictures, literary works, and visual art. Amendments include adding illicit labels to counterfeit labels and expanding the scope to include equipment used in manufacturing counterfeit or illicit labels. The amendment expands civil remedies for copyright owners affected by counterfeit or illicit labels, allowing them to bring a civil action in court. The amendment allows copyright owners to bring civil action in court for violations of copyright law, granting the court discretion to issue injunctions and impound infringing materials. The court has the authority to grant injunctions, order impounding of infringing materials, and award attorney fees and costs to the injured party in cases of copyright law violations. The court can impound articles involved in copyright violations and award attorney fees, actual damages, and profits to the injured party. The court can award attorney fees, actual damages, and profits to the injured party for copyright violations. The court can award actual damages and profits to the injured party for copyright violations, calculated based on the value of the infringing materials. The court calculates actual damages for copyright violations by multiplying the value of infringing materials by the quantity of those materials. The value of infringing materials for copyright violations is determined by multiplying the retail value of authorized copies by the quantity of phonorecords, copies, or works of visual art with counterfeit labels or packaging. The value of infringing materials for copyright violations is determined by multiplying the retail value of authorized copies by the quantity of phonorecords, copies, or works of visual art with counterfeit labels or packaging. The value of a phonorecord, copy, or work of visual art is defined based on the retail value of authorized versions for different types of copyrighted works. The value of infringing materials for copyright violations is determined by multiplying the retail value of authorized copies by the quantity of phonorecords, copies, or works of visual art with counterfeit labels or packaging. This value is based on the retail value of authorized versions for different types of copyrighted works such as sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and pictorial, graphic, or sculptural works. The value of infringing materials for copyright violations is determined by multiplying the retail value of authorized copies by the quantity of phonorecords, copies, or works of visual art with counterfeit labels or packaging. The injured party may elect to recover statutory damages of not less than $2,500 for each violation of copyright infringement. The injured party may choose to recover statutory damages for copyright infringement, ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 per violation. The court has the discretion to triple the damages for subsequent violations. The court may increase an award of damages under this subsection by 3 times the amount for subsequent violations within 3 years. A civil action must be commenced within 3 years of discovering the violation. The civil action must be commenced within 3 years of discovering the violation of subsection (a). A conforming amendment is made to the item relating to section 2318 in the table of sections for chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code. SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability or limitations under sections 512, 1201, or 1202 of Title 17, United States Code. They also do not apply to the electronic transmission of certain documents described in Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability or limitations under sections 512, 1201, or 1202 of Title 17, United States Code. It also does not apply to the electronic transmission of counterfeit labels or documentation described in Title 18, United States Code. The amendments made by this title do not affect fair use under section 107 of Title 17, United States Code, for genuine certificates, licensing documents, registration cards, labeling components, or documentation described in Title 18, United States Code. The "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act" is the short title for Title II, which amends the Trademark Act of 1946. Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include a new subsection stating that in cases of violation, it will be presumed willful if false contact information was knowingly provided. The new subsection in Section 35 of the Trademark Act of 1946 establishes a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information was knowingly provided in connection with a domain name used in the violation. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. The provision includes a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. This does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as per section 45 of the Act. The provision establishes a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement if false contact information is knowingly provided when registering a domain name used in connection with the infringement. This does not limit what may be considered willful infringement under this subsection. The term 'domain name' is defined as per section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of a felony offense involving the false registration of a domain name. The maximum imprisonment for the offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less, if the domain name was used knowingly in the course of the offense. The term "falsely registers" is defined as registering in a way that prevents identification or contact with the person who registers. The sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of a felony offense involving false domain name registration includes doubling or increasing the maximum imprisonment by 7 years if the domain name was knowingly used in the offense. "Falsely registers" means registering in a way that hinders identification or contact with the registrant. The term "domain name" is defined in section 45 of the Act approved on July 5, 1946. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and act in accordance with the sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of a felony offense involving false domain name registration. The term "domain name" is defined in the Act approved on July 5, 1946. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines to deter felony offenses carried out online using a domain name with false contact information. The Sentencing Commission will amend guidelines to enhance sentences for felony offenses committed online using false contact information with a domain name. The Sentencing Commission will provide sentencing enhancements for felony offenses involving false contact information used in registering a domain name. The term "domain name" is defined as per section 45 of the relevant Act. The subsection provides penalties for using false contact information when registering a domain name, with the definition of "domain name" as per the relevant Act. SEC. 205. CONSTRUCTION. This section clarifies that the rights of free speech and press are not affected by activities related to domain name registration. It also emphasizes that courts have discretion in determining damages, relief, and terms of imprisonment for intellectual property rights infringement. TITLE III--COURTS

SEC. 301. ADDITIONAL PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE DISTRICT OF COLORADO. Section 85 of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Colorado Springs," after "Boulder."

SEC. 302. PLACE OF HOLDING COURT IN THE NORTHERN DISTRICT OF NEW YORK. Section 112(a) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to include "Plattsburgh," after "Malone."
